awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Correlating Molecular Structure and Activity in Boron-containing ODH Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
As the world population grows, the demand for consumer goods, which are made from building-block chemicals such as ethylene and propylene, increases. The project focuses on discovery of energy-efficient catalysts for the production of these chemical building-blocks from natural gas with minimal generation of undesired by-products such as carbon dioxide.  Preliminary studies by the investigators have shown exceptional promise of boron-containing catalysts, but deeper, atomic-level understanding is needed to further improve the catalyst performance and durability.  The project will utilize a combination of new catalyst synthesis protocols, state-of-the-art solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance imaging, and computational methods to obtain the needed atomic-level understanding, and use that insight to design improved catalysts.  The research will support U.S. clean-energy security through its potential for the efficient conversion of our nation's vast shale gas resources to value-added fuels and chemicals. 

Oxidative Dehydrogenation (ODH) of light alkanes is a promising alternative for the production of important chemical building blocks. However, despite decades of research, a highly selective catalyst has remained elusive, as over-oxidation is a facile and thermodynamically favored process. Recent studies by the lead investigator's group has demonstrated that boron-containing catalysts (hBN, BNNT, WB, among others) are highly selective catalysts for the ODH of light alkanes. For propane ODH, propylene selectivity as high as 80% can be obtained up to 20% conversion, compared to 60% propylene selectivity at 10% propane conversion for the state-of-the-art vanadium oxide-based catalyst. Given the recent discovery of this class of materials as ODH catalysts, there are many fundamental questions that need to be answered regarding the active sites and their formation. Controlled synthesis, state-of-the-art solid-state NMR (SSNMR) spectroscopy, and computational modelling will be utilized to gain insights into the catalytically active site(s) and build up a structure-performance relationship for boron-containing ODH catalysts. The work will contribute to a molecular-level understanding of a complex problem that is of industrial importance. Our multidisciplinary approach comprised of synthesis, SSNMR characterization, catalytic testing, and computational modelling will train the participating students to use information from a variety of fields to develop a detailed picture of a complex system. Additionally, the collaborative nature of this work will help the students grow as productive members of a research team. Beyond the targeted reactions, the study will be of value to the broader catalysis community because of the generalized catalytic insights and the methods developed for characterization of heterogeneous materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
With support from the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Division in the Directorate of Engineering, the Rossini group at Iowa State University has developed solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy approaches for the structural characterization of boron oxide heterogeneous catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane to propylene. The research supported by this award was performed in collaboration with the group of Professor Ive Hermans (University of Wisconsin-Madison), whose group synthesized and tested the ODH catalysts.

This award resulted in 13 peer-reviewed publications. Several of these publications describe the synthesis of novel ODH catalysts. These catalysts were obtained by supporting suitable boron precursors on silica, zeolites, or activated carbon. In particular the latter material obtained by supporting boric acid on carbon was found to be an effective ODH catalyst that offered similar activity and selectivity to more expensive boron nitride based materials. However, all of the synthesized materials are amorphous, consequently it was challenging to probe the molecular-level structure of the boron atoms. To address this problem we developed solid-state NMR spectroscopy approaches. Specifically, we showed that the state-of-the-art 35 Tesla NMR spectrometer located at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory could be used to enhance the resolution and sensitivity of 11B solid-state NMR experiments on boron-based ODH catalysts. With the 35 T NMR spectrometer we were able to perform 11B two-dimensional (2D) NMR experiments that elucidated the connectivity and proximity of the boron atoms in the ODH catalysts. These experiments suggested that highly active ODH catalysts consisted of clusters of boron oxide and hydroxide atoms. To further probe the local structure of the boron atoms we devised methods that enabled heteronuclear 11B-17O 2D NMR experiments to be performed. These experiments confirmed the existence of a disordered oxide and hydroxide network when boric acid is supported on activated carbon.

This award also supported solid-state NMR studies of other heterogeneous catalysts. For example, we devised methods to enable acquisition of 195Pt solid-state NMR spectra of silica-supported platinum compounds. We also applied solid-state NMR spectroscopy to understand the structure of heterogeneous catalysts for olefin polymerization.

This project also had several associated broader impacts. Funds from this award directly supported the training of 3 graduate student researchers. The catalysts developed in this project may find use in industrial ODH processes. The NMR methods demonstrated in this project should also enable the study of other heterogeneous catalyst materials.

 


Last Modified: 02/18/2024
Modified by: Aaron J Rossini

Image
  • (Left) Homonuclear 11B 2D correlation spectrum illustrating the proximity of different boron structural units. (Right) Structural model of an oxidized boron layer growing off the surface of hexagonal boron nitride. Adapted with permission from Dorn et al., ACS Catalysis, 2020, 10, 13852-13866.
    Aaron J. Rossini
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Aaron J Rossini
    NMR spectra and structural models of boron oxide layers on boron nitride
por.por_txt_cntn:
With support from the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Division in the Directorate of Engineering, the Rossini group at Iowa State University has developed solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy approaches for the structural characterization of boron oxide heterogeneous catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of propane to propylene.The research supported by this award was performed incollaboration with the group of Professor Ive Hermans (University of Wisconsin-Madison), whose group synthesized and tested the ODH catalysts.


This award resulted in 13 peer-reviewed publications. Several of these publications describe the synthesis of novel ODH catalysts. These catalysts were obtained by supporting suitable boron precursors on silica, zeolites, or activated carbon. In particular the latter material obtained by supporting boric acid on carbon was found to be an effective ODH catalyst that offered similar activity and selectivity to more expensive boron nitride based materials. This award also supported solid-state NMR studies of other heterogeneous catalysts. This project also had several associated broader impacts. Funds from this award directly supported the training of 3 graduate student researchers. The NMR methods demonstrated in this project should also enable the study of other heterogeneous catalyst materials.
